title: [BUGFIX] update star_analysis. Fixes issue #885

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: Hey @xarthisius , thanks for working on this!  I tried testing this out a little bit, but I'm having some problems.  I naively tried to run some of the docstring test, but it failed because I don't have the Bruzual-Charlot data files for generating the SEDs.  I looked through the existing narrative docs (http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/analyzing/analysis_modules/star_analysis.html), but the link to get the BC03 data files is dead.  When I look up a real link, I found one but there are a variety of datafiles we can download (http://www2.iap.fr/users/charlot/bc2003/galaxev_download.html), and it doesn't seem obvious which files we should get in order to allow BC03 or salpeter IMF to work.  Since you probably just went through this in testing / fixing this up, would you mind including a short snippet of what needs to happen here either in a comment or in the docs?
content.html: Hey Kacper Kowalik , thanks for working on this! I tried testing this out a little bit, but I'm having some problems. I naively tried to run some of the docstring test, but it failed because I don't have the Bruzual-Charlot data files for generating the SEDs. I looked through the existing narrative docs (http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/analyzing/analysis_modules/star_analysis.html), but the link to get the BC03 data files is dead. When I look up a real link, I found one but there are a variety of datafiles we can download (http://www2.iap.fr/users/charlot/bc2003/galaxev_download.html), and it doesn't seem obvious which files we should get in order to allow BC03 or salpeter IMF to work. Since you probably just went through this in testing / fixing this up, would you mind including a short snippet of what needs to happen here either in a comment or in the docs?

content.raw: I got mine from http://yt-project.org/files/bc03/
content.html: I got mine from http://yt-project.org/files/bc03/

content.raw: Are we planning to make this the standard location where people access these files?
content.html: Are we planning to make this the standard location where people access these files?

content.raw: I've moved it to standard location, see this [PR](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/website/pull-request/76/add-link-to-stellar-population-synthesis)
content.html: I've moved it to standard location, see this PR

content.raw: @chummels this look okay to you?  If so, I think you're on deck for pushing the button.
content.html: chummels this look okay to you? If so, I think you're on deck for pushing the button.

content.raw: By putting star_mass and star_creation_time into numpy arrays, they fail to act as YTArrays and so failures later occur when we try to use the `.in_units(X)` functions on them.  Why not just leave them as is and require they be `YTArrays`?
content.html: By putting star_mass and star_creation_time into numpy arrays, they fail to act as YTArrays and so failures later occur when we try to use the .in_units(X) functions on them. Why not just leave them as is and require they be YTArrays?

content.raw: As far as I can tell, `self.volume` never gets used.
content.html: As far as I can tell, self.volume never gets used.

content.raw:
Hey @xarthisius , thanks for all of the work you've put into this!  Unfortunately, it seems like there is still some stuff that needs to be done to get this up to speed.  As you note, there are no updated docs on how to use this, so I tried to put together a test script to test your PR.  This is what I culled from the existing 2.x docs:  http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5402/ .  Perhaps this is a good starting point for writing a test and updating the docs?  I'm happy to help where I can.

One thing I did note is that when I run this test script, I get failures at a few different points in the code.  I tried to note some of them below.

It might be good also to make the bc03 files into a tarred and gzipped file (without the various index.html files present in that dir), so that one can just wget the whole file and then untar it.  Right now it is a bit cumbersome to download all the files in the sample directory.
content.html:
Hey Kacper Kowalik , thanks for all of the work you've put into this! Unfortunately, it seems like there is still some stuff that needs to be done to get this up to speed. As you note, there are no updated docs on how to use this, so I tried to put together a test script to test your PR. This is what I culled from the existing 2.x docs: http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5402/ . Perhaps this is a good starting point for writing a test and updating the docs? I'm happy to help where I can.

One thing I did note is that when I run this test script, I get failures at a few different points in the code. I tried to note some of them below.

It might be good also to make the bc03 files into a tarred and gzipped file (without the various index.html files present in that dir), so that one can just wget the whole file and then untar it. Right now it is a bit cumbersome to download all the files in the sample directory.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: Updated docs and fixed couple of bugs. As for bc03 files into a tarred and gzipped into single file: it already happened and you approved that pull request to the website. FTR it's available [here](http://yt-project.org/data/bc03.tar.gz) :-)
content.html: Updated docs and fixed couple of bugs. As for bc03 files into a tarred and gzipped into single file: it already happened and you approved that pull request to the website. FTR it's available here :-)

content.raw: Ugh, you're right.  I thought you had just added the bc03 directory with all the junk in it to the  yt-project.org/data location.  the gzipped file looks great.  I'll check over the docs and test this bad boy out.
content.html: Ugh, you're right. I thought you had just added the bc03 directory with all the junk in it to the yt-project.org/data location. the gzipped file looks great. I'll check over the docs and test this bad boy out.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: Is this paragraph still relevant?  Since you're passing YTArrays, which are omni-unit, doesn't this not apply anymore?
content.html: Is this paragraph still relevant? Since you're passing YTArrays, which are omni-unit, doesn't this not apply anymore?

content.raw: Here as well, should we be passing YTQuantities, or are simple thresholds OK as long as the user makes sure they're in the right units?
content.html: Here as well, should we be passing YTQuantities, or are simple thresholds OK as long as the user makes sure they're in the right units?

content.raw: Here again, I don't think units are relevant anymore.
content.html: Here again, I don't think units are relevant anymore.

content.raw: Perhaps choosing ds.quan(1, 'Myr') here?  I'm not sure passing 1e7 as a string will actually work as you have it here.
content.html: Perhaps choosing ds.quan(1, 'Myr') here? I'm not sure passing 1e7 as a string will actually work as you have it here.

content.raw: Don't these just need to be YTArrays without ref to the units?
content.html: Don't these just need to be YTArrays without ref to the units?

content.raw: Oh, I see, you're making it so people *can* specify normal np.arrays if they want to as long as they're in the right units.
content.html: Oh, I see, you're making it so people can specify normal np.arrays if they want to as long as they're in the right units.

content.raw: You removed volume from the docstrings, but it is still in the API.
content.html: You removed volume from the docstrings, but it is still in the API.

content.raw: This looks great so far, @xarthisius .  Sorry for all of the comments--mostly pretty minor, I think.  Aside from all the minor comments, I think this just needs a cookbook recipe and a test, which can both just be adaptations of that sample script you've been working with or the one from above.  Other than that, it's almost there.  Great job!
content.html: This looks great so far, Kacper Kowalik . Sorry for all of the comments--mostly pretty minor, I think. Aside from all the minor comments, I think this just needs a cookbook recipe and a test, which can both just be adaptations of that sample script you've been working with or the one from above. Other than that, it's almost there. Great job!

content.raw: @MatthewTurk : I'm curious why you merged this when I didn't have a chance to finalize and make sure everything worked here?  I had a busy weekend and was planning to look at it today.  Despite being labeled as a "bugfix", this was a major effort by @xarthisius to bring broken functionality up to speed, and I think it needed to be fully vetted, potentially by multiple people.  Since I've been the one pulling in the changesets, testing them, and reading the docs to make sure they made sense (when they previously have not in earlier versions of this PR), I thought my participation was a significant portion of making this code work.  I'm a little surprised that you just decided to merge it all in.
content.html: Matt Turk : I'm curious why you merged this when I didn't have a chance to finalize and make sure everything worked here? I had a busy weekend and was planning to look at it today. Despite being labeled as a "bugfix", this was a major effort by Kacper Kowalik to bring broken functionality up to speed, and I think it needed to be fully vetted, potentially by multiple people. Since I've been the one pulling in the changesets, testing them, and reading the docs to make sure they made sense (when they previously have not in earlier versions of this PR), I thought my participation was a significant portion of making this code work. I'm a little surprised that you just decided to merge it all in.

content.raw: This is probably worth bringing up on yt-dev.
content.html: This is probably worth bringing up on yt-dev.

description:
I've updated `sfr_spectrum` a bit. It should now use units in a consistent fashion. Please be aware that even though it doesn't currently fail, I cannot guarantee it generates sane results. 

As a bonus, all docstrings in this module can now be used as doctests. You'll need to run:

```
nosetests -v --with-doctest analysis_modules/star_analysis/sfr_spectrum.py
```

from the root directory of yt repository.

You can test this PR by running:

```
hg pull http://bitbucket.org/xarthisius/yt -B bug_885
hg update -C bug_885
python setup.py build_ext -i
```

in your clone of yt's repository, provided that you have installed yt using:

```
python setup.py develop --prefix=...
``` 

UPDATES:

  * use units more consistently
  * updated docs

TODO:

  * test, test, test...
